  physical_appearance: This is an illuminated collage consisting of acrylic-dyed coloured rice paper pressed together. Abstract and non-representational
 its layering shines through when the light is turned on. Bulbs are arranged within the glass panel (behind the most exterior surface) and has a power cord that leads to an adaptor which when plugged in
 lights up the entire work. Composition wise
 particularly striking are two hemispherical blotches of blue along the right edge of the work
 the yellow
 red
 and orange dyed paper presses.

  sgcool_label_text: Rodolfo Paras-Perez (1934-2011) or Rod. Paras-Perez
 as he frequently used in texts he authored
 is a respected Philippine artist and art historian. In the 1960s
 Paras-Perez created illuminated collages
 made of acrylic-dyed rice paper pressed between glass and lighted from behind. They were seen as quite experimental for its time
 using static light to expose and highlight the layers composing the collage. The works combine the growing influence of collage with an early experimentation with using lighting as a medium. As collages of various layers of coloured paper
 the works are also abstract
 in line with the vogue of abstract art at that time. The abstract form and the effort to expose the collage process through lighting provides visual intrigue and elicits more thinking on the part of the viewer on composition and method. Paras-Perez has said
 “an image should be ambiguous enough to slide into several meanings. In a collage
 one can use several layers of forms to sustain interest.”

metadata.physical_appearance: This is an illuminated collage consisting of acrylic-dyed coloured rice paper pressed together. Abstract and non-representational, its layering shines through when the light is turned on. Bulbs are arranged within the glass panel (behind the most exterior surface) and has a power cord that leads to an adaptor which when plugged in, lights up the entire work. Composition wise, particularly striking are two hemispherical blotches of blue along the right edge of the work, the yellow, red, and orange dyed paper presses.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: Rodolfo Paras-Perez (1934-2011) or Rod. Paras-Perez, as he frequently used in texts he authored, is a respected Philippine artist and art historian. In the 1960s, Paras-Perez created illuminated collages, made of acrylic-dyed rice paper pressed between glass and lighted from behind. They were seen as quite experimental for its time, using static light to expose and highlight the layers composing the collage. The works combine the growing influence of collage with an early experimentation with using lighting as a medium. As collages of various layers of coloured paper, the works are also abstract, in line with the vogue of abstract art at that time. The abstract form and the effort to expose the collage process through lighting provides visual intrigue and elicits more thinking on the part of the viewer on composition and method. Paras-Perez has said, “an image should be ambiguous enough to slide into several meanings. In a collage, one can use several layers of forms to sustain interest.”
